designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the

of any territory or area

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.   The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  is  in  the  preliminary  stages  of  reengaging  in 
economic policy advice and capacity development with the Government of the Republic of the 
Union of Myanmar. ADB adopted a three-phased process of reengagement with Myanmar in 
early 2012: phase I—preparation of initial economic and sector assessments as an extension of 
work  done  under  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS)  Program;  phase  II—conduct  of 
comprehensive sector assessments, capacity and institutional support, and project preparation; 
and  phase  III—resumption  of  lending  operations,  subject  to  satisfactory  progress  in  the 
country’s engagement with the international community and clearing of its arrears. ADB has 
completed phase I and is moving toward phase II by preparing for technical assistance (TA) 
operations focused on capacity building and institutional strengthening. This CDTA will support 
the implementation of the Interim Country Partnership Strategy for Myanmar, 2012-2014. 
 
2.  The government has requested capacity development TA to support its economic reform 
agenda. The TA is designed to strengthen the capacity of the government to develop and 
implement policies through a combination of policy advice, learning programs, workshops and 
seminars, and exposure to experiences from neighbor countries that faced similar challenges. 
Given that the capacity constraints are overwhelming and resources limited, the proposed TA 
will be selective in its interventions. It will improve the capacity of civil servants in government 
ministries and related public companies, although support to divisions and states could also be 
considered. The sectors to be included in the TA have been selected according to government 
priorities and the potential for ADB support based on preliminary needs assessments, strategies, 
and road maps. The government concurs with the impact, outcome, outputs, and key activities 
as presented in the design and monitoring framework in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.   The  new  government  is  implementing  a  broad  set  of  reforms  as  it embarks  on  a 
remarkable transition to build an economy that will benefit all citizens. Some major ongoing 
initiatives concern exchange rate unification, reform of land and investment laws, amendment to 
the Central Bank Act, finance sector reforms, and reform of the trade union law. These reforms 
offer  a  unique  opportunity  for  the  country  to  lay  the  foundations  for  a  brighter  and  more 
prosperous future for its people. The political and economic developments since early 2011 
open unprecedented opportunities for Myanmar to catch up with its neighbors and increase its 
per capita gross domestic product, one of the lowest in Southeast Asia at about $860; reduce 
the poverty rate from the current 26% to 16% of the country’s 60 million people; and improve 
human development indicators (Myanmar is near the bottom of the list at 149  out of 187 
countries). The changes and speed of reform have been impressive, but the challenges are 
complex and numerous. 
 
4.  The country is facing several binding development constraints, including (i) a weak 
economic  policy  framework  and  environment  that  needs  urgent  reforms  to  maintain 
macroeconomic  stability,  strengthen  public  finance,  promote  private-sector-led  trade  and 
investment, and provide timely and reliable statistics to inform policy decisions; (ii) limited 
capacity of government civil servants for formulating and managing the policy and institutional 
reform process, coordinating among themselves, and managing external assistance; (iii) weak 
public  institutions  that have  difficulties to  effectively  support the  economic reform  process,

efficiently provide essential public services, and develop and enforce strategies, plans, laws, 
rules, regulations and standards; and (iv) lack of efficient physical infrastructure to support trade 
and investment in agriculture, manufacturing, and industry, as well as to provide a sufficient 
level of services to both the urban and rural populations.  
   
5.  The country needs to embark on a comprehensive and well-sequenced program of 
reforms if it is to realize its potential. The regulatory, legal, and policy environment needs 
upgrading to facilitate the participation of the private sector, promote investment, and diversify 
the economy. The government needs to develop strategies, investment plans and incentives, 
and generate  adequate fiscal  resources  to  expand  access to  electricity,  water  supply  and 
sanitation, and transport, as well as to improve health, education, and social protection systems. 
Agriculture, which employs about 70% of the population, has great potential for improvement, 
but is in great need of land reform, expansion of credit to farmers, more public investment in 
rural infrastructure, and better seeds, fertilizers, extension services, and post-harvest facilities. 
 
6.  The capacity of existing socioeconomic policymaking institutions in Myanmar is limited 
and needs to be bolstered if appropriate economic policy reforms are to be designed and 
implemented successfully. Strengthening these institutions and giving them more independence 
in decision making in their areas of responsibility would increase accountability and contribute to 
better governance and greater transparency and efficiency. The Myanmar civil service has a 
critical role to play in this reform process. However, the majority of the civil servants have limited 
exposure to modern public sector management and good governance practices. They have had 
very  few  opportunities  to  develop  new  techniques  and  skills,  to  learn  lessons  from  other 
countries, or to access high-quality policy advice.  
 
7.  To avoid duplication and overstretching of the government’s absorptive capacity, the TA 
will be implemented in consultation with other development agencies that are providing related 
assistance to the government. The TA takes into account lessons learned from other capacity-
building  TA  projects,  especially  the  need  for  strong  government  ownership  for  TA  to  be 
successful and sustainable. The TA also builds on and complements other capacity-building TA 
projects. In particular, it will harness the experience developed under the ADB-financed GMS 
Phnom  Penh  Plan for Development  Management,2 which  since  2005  has  provided  limited 
support to improve the capacity of civil servants through learning programs outside Myanmar. 
 
8.  Policy advisors will support selected government agencies in preparing the new policy 
agenda,  in  line  with  the  government  strategy  to  reduce  poverty  and  promote  sustainable 
economic growth. Advisors placed in key ministries will work closely with government officials to 
assist them in the preparation of policy papers, plans, strategies, laws, or regulations. They will 
also suggest improvements to management systems, policies, and procedures in the ministries 
through the preparation of institutional development plans. These will be complemented by the 
preparation of capacity-building plans based on training needs assessments, in-country training 
programs based on demand, and out-of-country programs to learn lessons and best practices 
from neighbor countries. The TA will also support workshops, seminars, and conferences to 
share knowledge and discuss economic development and policy issues.

and promotes regional cooperation in the countries of the GMS.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact will be the implementation of effective and efficient policies and strategies in 
key sectors. The outcome will be for participating ministries to adopt effective and efficient 
policies, strategies, plans, laws, or regulations in their sectors.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  Three outputs are envisaged for the TA with key activities as follows:  
 
11.   Output 1: Institutional capacity of ministries to design policies and strategies is 
strengthened. Key activities will encompass (i) strategic and policy advice by long-term and 
short-term national and international experts placed as advisors in key ministries, and (ii) design 
of initial institutional development plans (strategic plans and organization development) in select 
ministries or groups of ministries. The advisors will work closely with the civil servants and 
ministers on developing or updating policies, plans, strategies, or legislation, as demanded by 
the ministries. Transfer of knowledge and skills, and on-the-job training activities, from the 
advisors to the civil servants will be a key component of this output. 
 
12.  Output 2: Myanmar government officials acquire knowledge and develop skills. 
Activities will include (i) a training needs assessment within and across selected ministries; (ii) a 
capacity-building  plan  that  will  determine  priority  learning  needs  in  line  with  institutional 
development;  (iii) training in public policy and development management (managing change, 
public  management,  project  management,  negotiations,  building  of  teams,  leadership); 
(iv) technical and policy training programs for specific sectors in which ADB could support 
Myanmar (planning, finance and trade, public financial management, energy, transport, urban 
and water supply, agriculture and natural resources, and education); and (v)  training programs 
to familiarize key civil servants with ADB operations, policies, instruments, and procedures 
(project design and implementation, economic and financial analyses, environmental and social 
safeguards, procurement). The in-country training programs will focus on middle and senior 
management in central and key line ministries. The programs will be designed and implemented, 
when feasible, in partnership with Myanmar education and training institutions such as the 
Myanmar  Development  Resource  Institute,  Union  of  Myanmar  Federation  of  Chambers  of 
Commerce and Industry, Union Civil Service Board, and the Myanmar–Singapore Training 
Center (under the Initiative for ASEAN Integration), among others. The sector divisions of ADB's 
Southeast Asia Department will lead capacity-building activities for their sectors. ADB staff in 
other departments (Central Operations Services Office, Controller's Department, Regional and 
Sustainable Development Department, and Strategy and Policy Department) may contribute to 
the training on ADB policies and procedures. 
 
13.  Output 3: Good practices, lessons learned, and experiences from other countries 
are disseminated. Activities include out-of-country, on-the job training attended by a cross-
section of civil servants from various ministries to learn lessons from other ASEAN countries 
and promote cooperation between developing countries. ADB resident missions will assist the 
selection  of  government  counterparts,  facilitators,  and  capacity-building  partners  in  their 
respective countries. 
 
14.  The  preliminary  sector  assessments,  strategies,  and  road  maps,  prepared  in  close 
coordination  with  government  ministries,  have  determined  the  initial  capacity  needs  of

4   
government institutions. A basic training needs assessment will also be prepared at the start of 
the TA, which will be used in design and delivery of the TA’s capacity development programs for 
Myanmar civil servants in relevant ministries, especially on policy design and implementation, 
development planning, project management, and service delivery.  
 
15.  The TA is expected to assist in the following areas: (i) macroeconomics, development 
planning, and statistics; (ii) energy; (iii) transport; (iv) agriculture and natural resources; and 
(v) urban development and water supply and sanitation. However, the TA is designed in a way 
that allows flexibility to support other sectors, cross-sector, and thematic areas depending on 
the emerging needs of and demands from the government.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.765 million, of which $1.5 million will be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  the  ADB  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF–other  sources).  The 
government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart salaries and office space. 
The detailed cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The Ministry of National Planning and Economic Development (MNPED) will be the 
executing agency. A sub-committee under the Aid Management Working Committee will be 
formed by the government, which will include senior officials from the participating ministries. 
The sub-committee will coordinate TA activities and serve as a forum for exchanging lessons in 
capacity development across ministries. A TA focal point in each participating ministry will 
provide administration support for the conduct of all activities. The sub-committee will also 
select participants for the training programs. ADB will attend the sub-committee meetings as an 
observer. 
 
18.  International and national consultants will be recruited by ADB in accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). TA implementation 
is anticipated to require 42 person-months of international consultancy and 39 person-months of 
national consultancy. The consultants will be recruited as individuals. Their outline terms of 
reference are in Appendix 3. Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with 
ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
They will be included in the TA expenditures if they are reasonable in amount and nature. The 
duration of the TA will be from December 2012 to November 2013. Office equipment will be 
procured in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to 
time). On completion of the TA, all equipment will be turned over to MNPED. The outputs of the 
TA will be disseminated through seminars, workshops, and publications. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Republic of the Union of Myanmar for Capacity Development and 
Institutional Support, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Work 
 
1.  Individual  consultants  (advisors)  will  be  engaged  to  provide  technical  and  advisory 
services to government ministries and improve the capacity of government officials to design 
and  implement  policies.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  require  42  person-months  of 
international consulting services and 39 person-months of national consulting services. The 
consultants will be based in Nay Pyi Taw and work inside the ministries.  
 
B.  Long-Term Sector Advisors 
 
2.  Statistics advisors (3 person-months international and 3 person-months national). The 
purpose of the assignment is to assist the Central Statistical Organization (CSO) at the Ministry 
of  National  Planning  and  Economic  Development  (MNPED)  in  charting  out  priorities  and 
strategies for building national statistics capacity in the short-to-medium term. The consultants 
will (i) assist the director general and other officials of CSO in (a) organizing the processes for 
undertaking a review of Myanmar’s national statistical system (NSS) in close collaboration with 
other experts and development partners engaged in this process and (b) developing a strategy 
for  building  NSS  capacity  in  terms  of  strengthening  institutional  coordination  mechanisms, 
statistics law, filling data gaps through periodic surveys, censuses and administrative collections 
for key statistics by CSO and other ministries or departments, use of international statistical 
standards, data dissemination, participation in the International Monetary Fund’s General Data 
Dissemination  System,  human  resource  and  information  and  communication  technology 
aspects of the NSS in the short, medium, and long term; (ii) organize and/or conduct related 
workshops in collaboration with other development partners and act as resource person; (iii) 
assess training needs (short, medium, and long term) and recommend in-country and external 
training programs for developing staff skills in relevant areas of official statistics and statistics 
education;  (iv)  conduct  needs-based,  short  in-house  training  sessions  for  CSO  and  other 
ministerial staff, and share good practices and lessons from other countries; (v) prepare an 
initial assessment report—with regard to elements in item (i) above—of the NSS and propose 
short- and medium-term priorities to improve the NSS; (vi) based on the assessment, and in 
consultation with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and MNPED, develop a proposal for a 2–
3-year ADB project to support statistics capacity building for Myanmar in collaboration with other 
development partners; (vii) explore possibilities of twining arrangements with the statistics office 
of a neighboring country; and (viii) perform other tasks that may be required by CSO authorities 
from time to time. The national statistics consultant will assist the international advisor in these 
tasks. 
 
3.  Agriculture and irrigation specialists (4 person-months international and 6 person-
months national). To strengthen the Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation (MOAI) of Myanmar 
and to support of its objective of agricultural modernization, the specialists will (i) provide 
technical advisory services to MOAI to help implement key policy objectives (e.g., land law, 
microfinance law, seed law, foreign direct investment law, pesticide law) and to crystallize the 
development of a coherent sector strategy, with priorities and investment plans. Prepare a 20-
page document on the full scope of the functions and the role of MOAI and all departments 
within MOAI; (ii) assist the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) in the 
validation of the National Medium-Term Priority Framework as an input for determining sector 
priorities, needs, and investment requirements. In close coordination with government officials 
and development partners, including FAO, the consultants will help define (a) performance 
targets  for  agricultural  production,  capital  stocks,  labor,  and  land;  and  (b)  investment

requirements  for  delivering  the  primary  agricultural  outputs  and  downstream  processing 
activities in the medium term (at least till 2020); (iii) draft a proposal for revitalizing MOAI to help 
it deliver the government’s sector objectives. The draft should contain an operational strategy 
for  implementing  the  revitalization  plan  and  specifically  discuss  potential  institutional 
coordination and management issues for the water resources subsector related to the Irrigation 
Department (dealing with gravity irrigation) and the Water Resource Utilization Department 
(dealing with pumped irrigation); (iv) hold extensive discussion with all stakeholders to aid the 
participation of the development partners in the implementation of MOAI's key policy objectives; 
(v) undertake an initial audit of human resources for implementing the revised and updated 
mandate of the ministry and develop a strategy to match staff to the new job descriptions, 
assisted by a task force made up of senior officials of MOAI; (vi) identify capacity gaps and 
design training programs to meet emerging needs; and (vii) support knowledge and training 
events organized or co-organized by ADB in Myanmar, and support other government planning 
and  coordination  needs  as  required.  The  assessment  of  existing  structures  and  possible 
solutions should be undertaken in close consultation with the pertinent project officers at ADB. 
 
4.  Energy sector advisors (3 person-months international and 4 person-months national). 
The advisors will be engaged to provide technical and advisory services to the Ministry of 
Energy (MOE), Ministry of Electric Power No. 1 (MOEP1), and Ministry of Electric Power No. 2 
(MOEP2); and improve the capacity of government officials to design and implement policies. 
The international energy sector advisor will (i) conduct participatory consultation within MOE to 
determine issues and areas requiring strategic and policy advice, and action plans for overall 
energy, energy efficiency, and renewable energy; (ii) set up the coordination mechanism among 
eight  energy-relevant  ministries—MOE,  Ministry  of  Mines  (coal),  Ministry  of  Science  and 
Technology (renewable), Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation (biofuels), Ministry of Industry 
(energy  efficiency),  Ministry  of  Environmental  Conservation  and  Forestry  (biomass  and 
safeguards), MOEP1, and MOEP2—for formulating overall energy sector policy, strategy, and 
planning,  and  promoting  energy  efficiency  and  renewable  energy  development,  including 
devising institutional development plans and identifying support needed and action plans; (iii) 
review the existing energy sector laws, policies, and strategies and prepare energy policy and 
strategy papers (except power sector); (iv) recommend energy sector reform for efficient and 
effective energy resource development in a sustainable way. Conduct workshops, seminars, 
and conferences for MOE; (v) conduct institutional development activities such as strategic 
planning, organizational performance assessment, and sector development planning for MOE; 
(vi) serve as resource persons (faculty) for in-country learning programs and work with the 
project team in the design, delivery, and evaluation of learning programs. Prepare an out-of-
country  program  to  learn  lessons  and  best  practices  from  neighboring  countries;  and  (vii) 
propose  new  policies,  systems,  and  procedures  for  consideration  by  MOE  in  line  with 
institutional development objectives. Advise management of MOE on any emerging needs and 
demand for energy sector policies and strategies. Prepare periodic reports on implementation 
progress for MOE. The national advisor will assist the international advisors in preparing policy 
and strategy papers, energy and power sector planning, and implementing training programs. 
The  national  advisor  will  also  help  translate  existing  laws  (with  amendments),  policies, 
strategies, and plans for the energy sector, power sector, oil and gas sector, coal sector, and for 
energy efficiency, renewable energy, and climate change into English; collect key information 
and  statistics on the  energy  sector; and prepare  a  database  or  handbook for the  use  by 
Myanmar officials. 
 
5.  Power sector advisor (international, 3 person-months). The advisor will (i) conduct 
participatory consultations within MOEP1 and MOEP2 to determine issues and areas requiring 
strategic  and  policy  advice,  and  action  plans  for  power  generation,  transmission,  and

plans and support requirements, and action plans for the power sector; (iii) review the existing 
power  sector  laws,  policies,  and  strategies  and  prepare  power  sector  policy  and  strategy 
papers;  (iv)  review  existing  studies  and  coordinate  with  other  consultants  and  advisors  to 
MOEP1 and MOEP2 to avoid duplication; (v) conduct workshops, seminars, and conferences 
for the power sector; (vi) conduct institutional development activities such as (but not limited to) 
strategic planning, organizational performance assessment, sector development planning, and 
action plan preparation for the power sector; (vii) serve as resource person (faculty) for in-
country  learning  programs  and  work  with  the  project  team  on  the  design,  delivery,  and 
evaluation of learning programs; (viii) prepare an out-of-country program to learn best practices 
from  neighboring  countries;  (ix)  propose  new  policies,  systems,  and  procedures  for 
consideration  by  MOEP1  and  MOEP2  in  line  with  institutional  development  objectives; 
(x) advise on public–private partnerships for power generation projects; (xi) advise management 
of MOEP1 and MOEP2 on any emerging needs and demand for power sector policies and 
strategies;  and  (xii)  prepare  periodic  reports  on  implementation  progress  for  MOEP1  and 
MOEP2. 
 
6.  Urban development and infrastructure advisor (international, 3 person-months). The 
advisor  will  support  the  Ministry  of  Construction  (MOC)  in  the  preparation  of  institutional 
development plans related to future urban sector and water investment activities,  including 
(i) preparation of an institutional development plan that entails the design of a capacity-building 
approach for MOC and the major cities in Myanmar. Besides capacity building, the institutional 
development plan will also deal with human resource development issues of MOC, and the 
implications of MOC’s nationwide operations; (ii) formulation of policy and strategy papers for 
the  urban  development  and  water  sector  to  cover  approaches  and  policies  to  urban 
infrastructure provision, including community infrastructure, and development of regional towns 
along  transport  corridors;  (iii)  workshops  to  present  and  discuss  concepts  and  strategies 
evolving from item (ii) above. These workshops will be primarily oriented to the needs of MOC 
and cities. The advisor will serve as a resource person for in-country learning programs and 
work with the TA coordinator on design, delivery, and evaluation of learning programs. These 
activities are expected to be implemented with the help of the Urban and Regional Development 
Institute, at the Yangon branch of MOC; (iv) conduct in-house strategic planning activities for 
MOC, and prepare organizational performance assessments and sector development action 
plans; and (v) prepare monthly reports on the implementation progress. 
 
7.  International  and  national  transport  policy  specialists  (3.5  person-months 
international and 6 person-months national). The specialists will (i) assess the requirements for 
improvements to and delivery of transport policies, both strategic and subsector-specific (e.g., 
roads, rail); (ii) assess how the policy landscape is influenced by institutional structures and, 
working with the institutional specialist, develop suitable alternative structures to better deliver 
these transport policies; (iii) liaise with development partners to fully understand their objectives 
for policy development in the transport sector; (iv) assess the capacity of ministries concerned 
with transport subsectors for developing, implementing, and monitoring their policies; (v) where 
needed, organize or assist capacity development training and workshops for these ministries; 
(vi) help the ministries prepare initial institutional and policy development plans, and (vii) file 
periodic reports on progress. The national transport policy specialist will assist in all tasks. 
 
8.  Institutional  transport  specialists  (3  person-months  international  and  6  person-
months national). The specialists will (i) assess the institutional structures of the ministries 
responsible for the transport sector in Myanmar; (ii) assess, along with the transport policy 
specialist, how the policy landscape is influenced by the institutional structures and prepare

Appendix    3         11 
possible and suitable alternative structures to better deliver strategic and subsector-specific 
transport policies; (iii) assess the institutional capacity of the ministries and prepare suitable 
capacity  development  programs  and  workshops;  (iv)  help  the  ministries  prepare  initial 
institutional  development  plans;  and  (vi)  file  periodic  reports  on  progress.  The  national 
institutional specialist will assist in each task. 
 
9.  Development  economist  and  planner  (international,  3.5  person-months).  The 
consultant will coordinate his or her work with the Thailand Resident Mission and relevant sector 
divisions of ADB's Southeast Asia Department throughout the assignment  and perform the 
following  tasks:  (i)  provide  technical  advice  to  MNPED  in  the  discharge  of  its  main 
responsibilities,  more  particularly  in  development  planning;  economic  policy  analyses, 
formulation, and coordination; donor coordination; and investment programming; (ii) conduct 
and/or arrange short in-house training seminars or workshops on MNPED areas of responsibility 
that need urgent strengthening; (iii) coordinate with other economic specialists who are engaged 
in areas related to the work of MNPED; and (iv) perform other tasks that may be requested by 
MNPED authorities from time to time, if necessary with the assistance of pertinent ADB units. 
 
C.  Short-Term Consultants  
 
10.  Short-term advisors (6 person-months international and 4 person-months national). 
The short-term consultants will be recruited depending on demand. Specific terms of reference 
will be prepared for each advisor and a request will have to be submitted by the ministry asking 
for support. The advisor will work closely with the capacity development specialist and TA 
coordinator, and will (i) conduct participatory consultations within the ministry in question to 
determine issues and areas requiring strategic and policy advice, and action plans; (ii) work 
closely with the ministry on developing an institutional development plan that specifies support 
and actions required; (iii) prepare policy and strategy papers; (iv) conduct workshops, seminars, 
and conferences in the ministry's sector; (v) conduct institutional development activities such as 
strategic planning, sector development planning, and action plan preparation; (vi) serve as 
resource persons (faculty) for in-country learning programs and work with the TA coordinator on 
the design, delivery, and evaluation of learning programs; (vii) propose new policies, systems, 
and  procedures  for  consideration  by  the  ministry  in  line  with  institutional  development 
objectives; and (viii) prepare periodic reports on the ministry's implementation progress. 
 
D.  TA Coordinators  
 
11.  Capacity development specialist (international, 10 person-months). The specialist and 
TA  coordinator  will  take  the  lead  in  TA  design  and  in  managing  its  implementation.  The 
specialist will be based in Myanmar and have a strong background in program management, as 
well as experience in and exposure to development management and capacity building. The 
specialist will (i) coordinate with the advisors to provide overall supervision, construct an overall 
work plan, and establish a monitoring framework for the TA, with baselines and indicators; (ii) 
work with the advisors on mechanisms for strategic and policy advice and institutional support 
for participating ministries, and in monitoring the implementation of action plans; (iii) work with 
and provide assistance to the advisors on mechanisms for strategic and policy advice and 
institutional support for the ministries; (iv) conduct, with the advisors, institutional development 
activities  in  the  ministries;  (v)  develop  framework  and  training  needs  assessments  in  key 
ministries in a participatory manner; (vi) facilitate or organize workshops with the ministries to 
build consensus on initiatives and activities under the capacity development plan, and in the 
process  encourage  ownership  and  commitment  of  the  ministries;  (vii)  establish  a  capacity 
development plan, (viii) work with faculty and resource persons on the design, delivery, and 
evaluation  of  learning  programs  (in-country  and  out-of-country);  (ix)  network  with  capacity

12   Appendix 3 
development partners and establish guidelines for their operations; (x) work with ministries on 
the preparation of institutional development plans; (xi) conceptualize, organize, and implement 
out-of-country  learning  programs  and  other  activities  on  cooperation  between  developing 
countries; (xii) organize and implement steering committee meetings, including agenda, concept 
papers,  notes,  and  presentations. Work  with  faculty  and  resource  persons  on  the  design, 
delivery, and evaluation of learning programs (in-country and out-of-country); (xiii) assist in 
teaching and supervise logistics of learning programs; (xiv) evaluate all learning programs and 
capacity development partners and provide recommendations for improvement, and establish 
performance monitoring and reporting systems for each advisor; and (xv) supervise budget 
preparation, monitor implementation, and prepare periodic reports on progress. 
    
12.  Analyst (national, 10 person-months) The analyst will assist day-to-day implementation 
and operations of the TA. The analyst will (i) coordinate TA implementation in Myanmar through 
regular interaction with participating government agencies and by facilitating the work of the 
advisors; (ii) assist in the planning and implementation of all TA activities; (iii) assist teaching 
and supervise logistics at selected in-country learning programs; (iv) coordinate with capacity 
development  partners  and  staff  of  ADB  resident  missions  the  administrative  and  logistical 
aspects of the out-of-country learning programs in collaboration with the Phnom Penh Plan 
Secretariat; (v) assist in organizing the steering committee meetings; (vi) prepare and monitor 
the budgets for in-country and out-of-country learning programs; (vii) develop and implement 
systems for budget monitoring; (viii) coordinate with consultants, government agencies, capacity 
development partners, and ADB resident missions the preparation of financial reports, which 
includes reviewing the liquidation of cash advances; (ix) develop and regularly update the TA 
alumni database, including preparing a detailed profile of participants in each learning program; 
(x) prepare and disseminate letters, memos and other documents required; (xi) facilitate the 
signing of all documents; (xii) maintain the records and filing system for the TA; and (xiii) provide 
routine administrative and logistical support to the other consultants and advisors.
